When checking if an OVERRIDE message has already been accepted, the system needs to know how to match the OVERRIDE message.

YES - The OVERRIDE suppression programs will check the message exactly, including all values in the message. If any of the values do not match then the OVERRIDE will be shown. If the OVERRIDE message is exactly the same as the one stored in the EB.OVERRIDE.APPROVED file then the OVERRIDE message will be suppressed.
NO - The OVERRIDE suppression programs will only check the Internal ID of the OVERRIDE, therefore if any of the text changes in the OVERRIDE the message will still be suppressed.

E.g. If the OVERRIDE CASH.FLOW.OVERDRAFT creates the message "15/01/02 18599 CASH FLOW OVERDRAFT GBP -2234.99" has already been created in a previous application but the application we are in creates the same OVERRIDE with the message "15/01/02 18599 CASH FLOW OVERDRAFT GBP
With EXACT.MATCH set to "NO" the system will compare the two OVERRIDE message ID's which are both CASH.FLOW.OVERDRAFT & therefore suppress the message.

With EXACT.MATCH set to "YES" not only are the message ID's checked but also the text. In this example the ID's match but the text is different because the overdraft amount has changed. Therefore this message will not be suppressed & will be displayed.

During the end of day processing the system call to accounting is replaced by a call to EOD ACCOUNTING. The important parameter in this call, as far as the user is concerned, is the field EOD ACCT MODE which can have one of the following values:-

SSS - (System Suspense) - any override condition will automatically have the answer 'YES' assigned to it if the entry is to an internal account. An entry to a customer account will be replaced by an entry to a suspense account in the event of an override condition being encountered.

NULL: -Any override condition will automatically have the answer 'YES' assigned to it if the entry is to an internal account. An entry to a customer account will not be replaced by an entry to a suspense account. Instead, the override messages will be incorporated in the STMT.ENTRY

Transaction Code Indicator (TRANSACTION.IND)

Certain types of accounting transactions are exempt from Dispo processing depending on the application used to generate the transaction/contract. For example, fees generated by a Funds Transfer transaction can cause the account to go into overdraft, this overdraft override is exempt from Dispo processing. This field indicates whether the exempt indicator on the transaction code should be used in determining if the override is exempt. If the field is set to YES, then the system must look at the exempt indicator on the transaction code.
Valid entries for this field are: YES, NO, or empty field.
YES in this field indicates that the transaction file is checked for the exempt indicator
NO, or null in this field indicates that the transaction file will not be checked, and the Dispo instructions specified on the OVERRIDE file should be followed

Conditional Override (CON.OVERRIDE)

Dispo overrides can be conditional on whether the customer has sufficient funds on their accounts. If the customer has sufficient funds then other Dispo overrides such as ‘Limit has expired’ can be prevented from going to DISPO. You can define whether certain overrides are dependent on other overrides.
In this field the user can specify the other override that this particular override is dependent on. The user is able to enter more than one override per application.

If an override has conditional overrides, and one of these conditional overrides is present on the contract, then the override will go to the dispo queue. However if none of the conditional overrides are on the contract then the override will not invoke dispo processing, that is, it will not go to the dispo queue.
Field is optional
Must be a valid Dispo Override. Ie. DISPO.ALLOWED field is set to YES.
